title: About
text:

Interests: ML, simulation, data viz, prototypes.
What you’ll find: work-in-progress notes, visuals, and links to projects/posts.

title: First sandbox notes
text:
Quick smoke test of code blocks:
import numpy as np
np.random.seed(0)
np.random.rand(3)
Inline viz idea: drop in Plotly/Altair/Observable embeds here later.

title: Job Matching Simulation: Yield-Driven Trap
text: This project reproduces the “too good for average schools, too bad for top schools” interview trap. Departments over-weight yield when selecting interviews, so mid-tier schools avoid very strong candidates (fear of rejection), top schools avoid weaker candidates, and strong candidates can get stranded.

title: Job Matching Simulation: Yield-Driven Trap
text:
Model sketch

Candidates: have a latent quality (q_i).
Departments: have tier (t_j), and one slot each.
Interview stage: each department interviews (K) candidates selected by score [ {ij} = q_i + p{ij}, p_{ij} = ((t_j - q_i) + s_{ij}) ] where (s_{ij}) is a signal bump; if (q_i t_j), (p_{ij}) is low (expected to reject). The yield term comes from a probability the candidate would accept an offer: [ p_{ij} = !((t_j - q_i) + s_{ij})] where () is logistic; if (q_i t_j), then (p_{ij}) is small (dept thinks “they won’t accept”). (s_{ij}) is a signal bump if candidate signals interest.
Offer stage (two variants): Decentralized/early offers: departments make offers to top interviewees; candidates may accept quickly, leaving congestion and mismatch. Centralized match (Deferred Acceptance / NRMP-style): stable matching on preferences after interviews.

Key levers: signal_slots (credible interest signals), mechanism ("decentralized" vs "da"), and interviews per dept K. Yield sensitivity comes from alpha (steepness) and lam (weight on yield).

title: Job Matching Simulation: Yield-Driven Trap
text:
Quick start
cd EJM_matching_simulation
python3 simulation.py
For plots in this post:
MPLCONFIGDIR=../Sandbox/.matplotlib python3 - <<'PY'
from simulation import run_scenarios, collect_scenario_metrics, plot_metric_bars, plot_interview_heatmap
import pathlib
outdir = pathlib.Path('Sandbox/posts/matching-simulation')
outdir.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)
scenarios = run_scenarios()
rows = collect_scenario_metrics(scenarios)
fig, ax = plot_metric_bars(rows); fig.savefig(outdir/'bars.png', dpi=200)
fig, ax, _ = plot_interview_heatmap(scenarios[0][1]); fig.savefig(outdir/'heatmap.png', dpi=200)
PY

title: Job Matching Simulation: Yield-Driven Trap
text:
Scenarios compared
base = dict(N=600, M=450, K=10, alpha=2.2, lam=1.4)
scenarios = [
    ("Bad eq: decentralized, no signals", {**base, "signal_slots": 0, "mechanism": "decentralized", "seed": 1}),
    ("Fix 1: DA match, no signals",       {**base, "signal_slots": 0, "mechanism": "da",            "seed": 1}),
    ("Fix 2: decentralized + signals",    {**base, "signal_slots": 3, "mechanism": "decentralized", "seed": 1}),
    ("Fix 3: DA + signals",               {**base, "signal_slots": 3, "mechanism": "da",            "seed": 1}),
    ("Fix 4: more interviews (K=18)",     {**base, "K": 18, "signal_slots": 0, "mechanism": "decentralized", "seed": 1}),
]

title: Job Matching Simulation: Yield-Driven Trap
text:
Metrics (higher is better unless noted)

fill_rate: share of departments that filled their position.
unemployment: share of candidates unmatched (lower is better).
stranded_top20_share: among top 20% of candidates by quality, share left unmatched (captures the trap).

title: Job Matching Simulation: Yield-Driven Trap
text:
Results overview



Scenario comparison


The bad equilibrium (decentralized, no signals) strands many strong candidates and leaves vacancies. DA alone boosts fill rate; signals help decentralized markets; more interviews partially mitigates the bottleneck.

title: Job Matching Simulation: Yield-Driven Trap
text:
Interview allocation diagnostic



Interview heatmap


Rows: department tier bins (low→high). Columns: candidate quality bins (low→high). Color: share of interviews. In the bad equilibrium, mid-tier rows are dim in the top-quality columns—mid-tier departments avoid the very best candidates. With signals/DA, those cells brighten, showing improved access for strong candidates.

title: Job Matching Simulation: Yield-Driven Trap
text:
Explore interactively
Open EJM_matching_simulation/simulation_exploration.ipynb: - Tweak params for signal_slots, mechanism, K, alpha, lam. - Run the single-scenario cell to see metrics and a mini bar chart. - Run the heatmap cell to see how interview allocation shifts.

title: Job Matching Simulation: Yield-Driven Trap
text:
What we should typically see (qualitatively)
With parameters like alpha≈2 (steep yield drop when candidate is “overqualified”) and a meaningful lam (departments care about yield), you’ll usually observe: - Bad equilibrium (decentralized, no signals): - Mid-tier departments interview fewer top candidates (mid_depts_interview_top10_share low). - Some high-quality candidates get stranded (stranded_top20_share non-trivial). - Match quality correlation can be weaker than expected, and/or fill rates can be worse. - Better outcomes with: 1. Centralized DA: reduces “exploding offers” and congestion; candidates don’t have to accept early and lose better options. 2. Limited signals: gives mid-tier departments a credible way to distinguish “top candidate who might actually accept” from “top candidate using us as a safety/throwaway.” 3. More interviews (higher K): reduces the interview bottleneck that amplifies errors from yield-guessing.

title: Job Matching Simulation: Yield-Driven Trap
section: Why this creates the “too good” problem (intuition)
text:
Why this creates the “too good” problem (intuition)

If acceptance probability falls sharply when (q_i t_j), then for a mid-tier dept:

interviewing the very best candidates is “wasting” interview slots (low chance of acceptance),
interviewing very weak candidates risks low quality,
so they cluster interviews around candidates “just above/below” their own tier.

If every mid-tier dept does this, strong candidates can end up with interviews only from the very top (too competitive) and the very bottom (where depts think yield is high), skipping the middle where they’d actually match well. That’s a coordination failure: individually rational interview strategies create a collectively worse assignment.

title: Job Matching Simulation: Yield-Driven Trap
section: Matching rules that tend to push toward a “good equilibrium”
text:
Matching rules that tend to push toward a “good equilibrium”
A. Centralized match after interviews (Deferred Acceptance)

Pros: reduces congestion, removes exploding-offer pressure, yields stable matches.
Doesn’t fully solve interview misallocation (if interview stage is the real bottleneck), but helps.

B. Credible interest signals (cheap talk → limited, costly, or verifiable)

A small number of signals (e.g., 3–5) can strongly improve interview allocation.
In the sim, signal_slots>0 pushes mid-tier schools to include “overqualified but interested” candidates.

C. Two-stage / tiered interviewing

Stage 1 broad interviews; Stage 2 “mutual interest” or “shortlist” with higher commitment.
Reduces wasted interviews on low-probability pairs.

D. Interview caps + coordinated timing

Interview caps reduce hoarding by top candidates and top departments.
Coordinated timelines reduce unraveling.
